ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: N/A
Question 12: This course is very similar in some ways to FES 800 (though in no way as comprehensive) and is therefore somewhat redundant.

The one member of my group who has a lot of excel experience did all of the modeling. I picked up a few tricks from her, but I wish we hadlearned how to do this modeling in the lectures. The lectures were very duplicative of other energy course offerings at FES. The hotelling and energy efficiency/discounting lectures in particular, and many of the readings, were repetitive. The energy strategy game is what sets the class apart, so I wish this were more of a formal focus during class time.
12 - The electricity strategy game was valuable. It was also somewhat valuable to hear a lot of the policy issues discussed in other FES courses from a different perspective.

I realized a little too late in the class that more Econ knowledge than what I had was necessary. The electricity strategy game, for example, would have been extremely difficult for me without the help of those in my group. People with a better concept of trading in markets will definitely do better. That being said, it's an interesting topic and Professor Campbell was great.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Covers a good variety of topics, discusses them in details without going too much into the nitty-gritty
Electricity Strategy Game
The electricity strategy game - particularly the auction and the stakeholder meeting and trading permits.
Energy Strategy Game

The ESG was very helpful and cleared up a lot of uncertainty I had about how electricity markets worked.There still are a few things that are unclear, but most of it I understand much better now.Also, the stuff on different forms of regulation was very good too. I'd keep that in there next year.
It provides a general overview of the energy markets including future challenges. It is well balanced between policy and markets analysis.
The reading material was very relevant, the class was of a good size making it interactive.The strategy game was a good introduction to wholesale electricity markets.
It was good to learn about a useful issue such as this, and the class was enjoyable.
The electricity strategy game!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: data and overview could be not just focused on the US.
Ideally, Profesor Campbell could work with Professor Gillingham to reduce course material overlap.
It could have been useful to explain the strategy for the different parts of the game more in class and discuss the game as it progresses a bit more.
I would spend a little more time discussing locational pricing - or at least post a basic reading on the subject.
There should just be a caveat for those without very much Econ under their belts (like maybe an indication in the course listing on Bluebook or OCS).

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It fits well - i want to learn more about how energy markets work and what are the important concepts to know. Good overview and introduction
Learning how these markets work is pretty foundational to anyone in the Energy track at F&ES. Vital material.
I'm an international relations student, and I thought it was important to learn about energy as that is a global issue.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: TO learn more about energy markets and how they work
To learn more about energy markets.
See #17.
I wanted to understand how energy markets worked.
I wanted to better understand energy markets.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, for most parts
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes, but I would have gained more if I had more of a background in the material.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Overall good experience - people were knowledgeable and willing to share workload
we all did what we are good at and already knew how to do, instead of learning new things

The group was able to explain and discuss the strategy for the game in more depth than was covered in class. The disadvantage was that since the group had very different backgrounds and levels of comfort with the material, not everyone in the group was able to get as much out of the game.
Peer-to-peer learning
It was good to be mixed with people of different skill sets and academic backgrounds.
Multidisciplinary work.
Yes, I think students benefit alot from each other working in teams on the ESG game and the strategy memo.
The group work was good in the sense thatother group members helped with parts of the game that I couldn't understand as well.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Good course - could learn a lot
Take it, but keep in mind that it overlaps with FES 800.
write down your rationale for decisions in the game as it happens, so you can remember when writing the memo

Take it if you need the credits because the game isinteresting and valuable, but if you are already taking a few other energy courses at FES in the spring, this one does not provide that much additional value.

For anyone who has also taken Gillingham's F&ES 800, this will have a fair amount of overlap. However, that's ok because (1) repetition is one of the keys to learning, and (2) the stuff that doesn't overlap is important knowledge to have.
Make sure you have a solid Econ foundation!
